controllers.base.control_primitives¶

Source: src\controllers\base\control_primitives.py

Module Overview¶

No module docstring available.

Mathematical Foundation¶

Control Law Composition¶

Primitive: Atomic control operation that can be composed into complex laws.

\[u = \mathcal{C}(u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_n)\]

Where \(\mathcal{C}\) is composition operator (sum, max, switching, etc.).

Additive Composition¶

Superposition principle for linear systems:

\[u = u_{ff} + u_{fb} + u_{robust}\]

Where:

  • \(u_{ff}\): Feedforward control (model-based)

  • \(u_{fb}\): Feedback control (error-driven)

  • \(u_{robust}\): Robustness term (disturbance rejection)

SMC example:

\[u = u_{eq} + u_{sw}\]

Saturation Primitive¶

Input saturation enforces actuator limits:

\[\begin{split}\text{sat}(u, u_{max}) = \begin{cases} u_{max}, & u > u_{max} \\ u, & |u| \leq u_{max} \\ -u_{max}, & u < -u_{max} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

Properties:

  • Non-linear (breaks superposition)

  • Lipschitz continuous: \(|\text{sat}(u) - \text{sat}(v)| \leq |u - v|\)

  • Monotonic: \(u > v \Rightarrow \text{sat}(u) \geq \text{sat}(v)\)

Deadband Primitive¶

Deadband ignores small errors (avoid actuator noise):

\[\begin{split}\text{deadband}(e, \delta) = \begin{cases} e - \delta, & e > \delta \\ 0, & |e| \leq \delta \\ e + \delta, & e < -\delta \end{cases}\end{split}\]

Typical: \(\delta = 3 \sigma_{noise}\)

Rate Limiter Primitive¶

Rate limiting prevents actuator slew violations:

\[u_k = \text{clip}(u_k^{desired}, u_{k-1} - \dot{u}_{max} \Delta t, u_{k-1} + \dot{u}_{max} \Delta t)\]

Example: \(\dot{u}_{max} = 1000\) N/s for hydraulic actuator

Low-Pass Filter Primitive¶

First-order filter reduces high-frequency content:

\[u_f = \frac{\omega_c}{s + \omega_c} u\]

Discrete implementation:

\[u_f[k] = \alpha u[k] + (1 - \alpha) u_f[k-1], \quad \alpha = \frac{\Delta t}{\Delta t + \tau}\]

Where \(\tau = 1/\omega_c\) is filter time constant.

Gain Scheduling Primitive¶

Non-linear gain varies with operating point:

\[K(\vec{x}) = K_0 + \sum_{i=1}^{n} K_i \phi_i(\vec{x})\]

Where \(\phi_i\) are basis functions (e.g., RBF, polynomial).

Linear interpolation example:

\[\begin{split}K(\theta) = \begin{cases} K_{low}, & \theta < \theta_{low} \\ K_{low} + \frac{K_{high} - K_{low}}{\theta_{high} - \theta_{low}} (\theta - \theta_{low}), & \theta_{low} \leq \theta \leq \theta_{high} \\ K_{high}, & \theta > \theta_{high} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

Anti-Windup Primitive¶

Problem: Integral windup when saturation active.

Solution: Conditional integration:

\[\begin{split}\dot{I} = \begin{cases} e, & u_{raw} = u_{sat} \quad \text{(no saturation)} \\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

Or back-calculation:

\[\dot{I} = e + \frac{1}{T_i} (u_{sat} - u_{raw})\]

Observer Primitive¶

State estimation from measurements:

\[\dot{\hat{x}} = A \hat{x} + B u + L(y - C \hat{x})\]

Where \(L\) is observer gain matrix.

Separation principle: Design observer and controller independently (for linear systems).

Composition Algebra¶

Commutative: \(u_1 + u_2 = u_2 + u_1\) (for linear)

Not commutative: \(\text{sat}(u_1 + u_2) \neq \text{sat}(u_1) + \text{sat}(u_2)\)

Associative: \((u_1 + u_2) + u_3 = u_1 + (u_2 + u_3)\)

Distributive (partial): For some operators

Architecture Diagram¶

graph TD A[Raw Control u_raw] --> B[Anti-Windup] B --> C[Rate Limiter] C --> D[Saturation] D --> E[Low-Pass Filter] E --> F[Deadband] F --> G[Final Control u] B --> H[Check: Saturation Active?] H -->|Yes| I[Halt Integration] H -->|No| J[Continue Integration] C --> K[Check: |u̇| ≤ u̇_max?] K -->|No| L[Clip Rate] K -->|Yes| C D --> M[Check: |u| ≤ u_max?] M -->|No| N[Saturate] M -->|Yes| D style A fill:#9cf style G fill:#9f9 style I fill:#f99 style L fill:#ff9 style N fill:#ff9

Usage Examples¶

Example 1: Saturation Primitive¶

from src.controllers.base.control_primitives import saturate

# Apply saturation to control signal
u_raw = 150.0  # Exceeds actuator limit
u_max = 100.0

u = saturate(u_raw, u_max)
print(f"Saturated control: {u:.1f} N")  # 100.0 N

# Vectorized saturation
u_raw_array = np.array([150.0, 50.0, -120.0, 30.0])
u_array = saturate(u_raw_array, u_max)
print(f"Saturated controls: {u_array}")  # [100, 50, -100, 30]

Example 2: Rate Limiter¶

from src.controllers.base.control_primitives import rate_limit

# Current and previous control
u_current = 80.0
u_previous = 40.0
dt = 0.01  # Time step
u_dot_max = 1000.0  # N/s

# Apply rate limiting
u_limited = rate_limit(u_current, u_previous, u_dot_max, dt)

# Maximum allowed change: 1000 * 0.01 = 10 N
# Requested change: 80 - 40 = 40 N
# Limited change: 10 N
print(f"Rate-limited control: {u_limited:.1f} N")  # 50.0 N

Example 3: Anti-Windup¶

from src.controllers.base.control_primitives import anti_windup_back_calculation

# PID-like controller with integral term
integral = 5.0  # Accumulated integral error
u_raw = 150.0   # Requested control
u_max = 100.0

# Saturated control
u_sat = saturate(u_raw, u_max)  # 100.0 N

# Back-calculation anti-windup
T_i = 1.0  # Integration time constant
integral_correction = (u_sat - u_raw) / T_i  # Negative (reduces integral)

integral_new = integral + integral_correction * dt
print(f"Integral before: {integral:.3f}")
print(f"Integral after:  {integral_new:.3f}")  # Reduced

Example 4: Low-Pass Filter¶

from src.controllers.base.control_primitives import low_pass_filter

# Noisy control signal
u_noisy = 50.0 + 5.0 * np.random.randn()

# Filter parameters
omega_c = 20.0  # Cutoff frequency (rad/s)
dt = 0.01
tau = 1.0 / omega_c  # Time constant

# Apply filter
u_filtered_prev = 48.0  # Previous filtered value
u_filtered = low_pass_filter(u_noisy, u_filtered_prev, tau, dt)

print(f"Noisy control:    {u_noisy:.2f} N")
print(f"Filtered control: {u_filtered:.2f} N")

Example 5: Complete Control Pipeline¶

from src.controllers.base.control_primitives import (
    saturate, rate_limit, low_pass_filter, deadband
)

# Control pipeline
class ControlPipeline:
    def __init__(self, u_max, u_dot_max, tau_filter, deadband_threshold):
        self.u_max = u_max
        self.u_dot_max = u_dot_max
        self.tau = tau_filter
        self.deadband = deadband_threshold
        self.u_prev = 0.0
        self.u_filtered_prev = 0.0

    def process(self, u_raw, dt):
        # 1. Deadband (ignore small errors)
        u1 = deadband(u_raw, self.deadband)

        # 2. Rate limiting (prevent slew violations)
        u2 = rate_limit(u1, self.u_prev, self.u_dot_max, dt)

        # 3. Saturation (enforce actuator limits)
        u3 = saturate(u2, self.u_max)

        # 4. Low-pass filter (reduce high-frequency content)
        u4 = low_pass_filter(u3, self.u_filtered_prev, self.tau, dt)

        # Update history
        self.u_prev = u3  # Before filtering for rate limiting
        self.u_filtered_prev = u4

        return u4

# Usage
pipeline = ControlPipeline(
    u_max=100.0,
    u_dot_max=1000.0,
    tau_filter=0.05,
    deadband_threshold=0.5
)

u_raw = -75.0  # Raw controller output
u_final = pipeline.process(u_raw, dt=0.01)
print(f"Final control: {u_final:.2f} N")

Complete Source Code¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#===================== src/controllers/base/control_primitives.py =====================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5from __future__ import annotations
  6import math
  7import numpy as np
  8from typing import Literal
  9
 10# --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 11# Positivity utilities
 12# --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 13
 14def require_positive(value: float | int | None, name: str, *, allow_zero: bool = False) -> float:
 15    """Validate that a numeric value is positive (or non‑negative).
 16
 17    Parameters
 18    ----------
 19    value : float or int or None
 20        The numeric quantity to validate.
 21    name : str
 22        The name of the parameter (used in the error message).
 23    allow_zero : bool, optional
 24        When True, a value of exactly zero is allowed; otherwise values must
 25        be strictly greater than zero.
 26
 27    Returns
 28    -------
 29    float
 30        The validated value cast to ``float``.
 31
 32    Raises
 33    ------
 34    ValueError
 35        If ``value`` is ``None``, not a finite number, or does not satisfy
 36        the positivity requirement.
 37
 38    Notes
 39    -----
 40    Many control gains and time constants must be positive to ensure
 41    stability in sliding‑mode and adaptive control laws【462167782799487†L186-L195】.
 42    Centralising positivity checks via this helper reduces duplicated logic
 43    across controllers and configuration validators.  Callers may still
 44    choose to perform their own validation before construction, but using
 45    this helper ensures consistent error messages and thresholds.
 46    """
 47    if value is None or not isinstance(value, (int, float)) or not math.isfinite(value):
 48        raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a finite number; got {value!r}")
 49    val = float(value)
 50    if allow_zero:
 51        if val < 0.0:
 52            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be ≥ 0; got {val}")
 53    else:
 54        if val <= 0.0:
 55            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be > 0; got {val}")
 56    return val
 57
 58# --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 59# Range validation utilities
 60# --------------------------------------------------------------------------
 61
 62def require_in_range(value: float | int | None, name: str, *, minimum: float, maximum: float, allow_equal: bool = True) -> float:
 63    """Validate that a numeric value lies within a closed or open interval.
 64
 65    Parameters
 66    ----------
 67    value : float or int or None
 68        The numeric quantity to validate.
 69    name : str
 70        The name of the parameter (used in the error message).
 71    minimum : float
 72        Lower bound of the allowed interval.
 73    maximum : float
 74        Upper bound of the allowed interval.
 75    allow_equal : bool, optional
 76        If True (default) the bounds are inclusive; if False the value
 77        must satisfy ``minimum < value < maximum``.
 78
 79    Returns
 80    -------
 81    float
 82        The validated value cast to ``float``.
 83
 84    Raises
 85    ------
 86    ValueError
 87        If ``value`` is ``None``, not finite, or lies outside the
 88        specified interval.
 89
 90    Notes
 91    -----
 92    Range constraints arise frequently in control law design; for
 93    example, a controllability threshold should be positive but small,
 94    whereas adaptation gains must lie within finite bounds to ensure
 95    stability【462167782799487†L186-L195】.  Centralising range checks
 96    avoids duplicating logic across the project and produces uniform
 97    error messages.
 98    """
 99    if value is None or not isinstance(value, (int, float)) or not math.isfinite(value):
100        raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a finite number; got {value!r}")
101    val = float(value)
102    if allow_equal:
103        if val < minimum or val > maximum:
104            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be in the interval [{minimum}, {maximum}]; got {val}")
105    else:
106        if val <= minimum or val >= maximum:
107            raise ValueError(f"{name} must satisfy {minimum} < {name} < {maximum}; got {val}")
108    return val
109
110def saturate(
111    sigma: float | np.ndarray,
112    epsilon: float,
113    method: Literal["tanh", "linear"] = "tanh",
114) -> float | np.ndarray:
115    """Continuous approximation of sign(sigma) within a boundary layer.
116    
117    Args:
118        sigma: Sliding surface value(s).
119        epsilon: Boundary-layer half-width in σ-space (must be > 0).  # ε is the half-width in σ-space.
120        method: "tanh" (default) uses tanh(sigma/epsilon);
121                "linear" uses clip(sigma/epsilon, -1, 1).
122    Returns:
123        Same shape as `sigma`.
124
125    Notes
126    -----
127    The boundary layer width ``epsilon`` should be chosen based on the
128    expected amplitude of measurement noise and the desired steady‑state
129    accuracy.  A larger ``epsilon`` reduces chattering but introduces
130    a finite steady‑state error; conversely, a smaller ``epsilon`` reduces
131    error but may increase high‑frequency switching【538884328193976†L412-L423】.
132
133    Raises:
134        ValueError
135            If ``epsilon <= 0`` or an unknown ``method`` is provided.
136    """
137    if epsilon <= 0:
138        raise ValueError("boundary layer epsilon must be positive")
139    s = np.asarray(sigma, dtype=float) / float(epsilon)
140    if method == "tanh":
141        return np.tanh(s)
142    if method == "linear":
143        # Warn users that the linear saturation approximates sign(sigma) poorly
144        # near zero.  A piecewise‑linear approximation yields a sharp transition
145        # at the boundary layer and can introduce larger steady‑state errors.
146        # Sliding‑mode control theory recommends smooth approximations such
147        # as tanh to mitigate chattering【676964782857750†L146-L149】.
148        import warnings
149        warnings.warn(
150            "The 'linear' switching method implements a piecewise‑linear saturation, "
151            "which approximates the sign function poorly near zero and can degrade "
152            "chattering performance.  Consider using 'tanh' for smoother control.",
153            RuntimeWarning,
154        )
155        return np.clip(s, -1.0, 1.0)
156    raise ValueError(f"unknown saturation method: {method!r}")

Functions¶

require_positive(value, name)¶

Validate that a numeric value is positive (or non‑negative).

Parameters¶

value : float or int or None The numeric quantity to validate. name : str The name of the parameter (used in the error message). allow_zero : bool, optional When True, a value of exactly zero is allowed; otherwise values must be strictly greater than zero.

Returns¶

float The validated value cast to float.

Raises¶

ValueError If value is None, not a finite number, or does not satisfy the positivity requirement.

Notes¶

Many control gains and time constants must be positive to ensure stability in sliding‑mode and adaptive control laws【462167782799487†L186-L195】. Centralising positivity checks via this helper reduces duplicated logic across controllers and configuration validators. Callers may still choose to perform their own validation before construction, but using this helper ensures consistent error messages and thresholds.

Source Code¶

 1def require_positive(value: float | int | None, name: str, *, allow_zero: bool = False) -> float:
 2    """Validate that a numeric value is positive (or non‑negative).
 3
 4    Parameters
 5    ----------
 6    value : float or int or None
 7        The numeric quantity to validate.
 8    name : str
 9        The name of the parameter (used in the error message).
10    allow_zero : bool, optional
11        When True, a value of exactly zero is allowed; otherwise values must
12        be strictly greater than zero.
13
14    Returns
15    -------
16    float
17        The validated value cast to ``float``.
18
19    Raises
20    ------
21    ValueError
22        If ``value`` is ``None``, not a finite number, or does not satisfy
23        the positivity requirement.
24
25    Notes
26    -----
27    Many control gains and time constants must be positive to ensure
28    stability in sliding‑mode and adaptive control laws【462167782799487†L186-L195】.
29    Centralising positivity checks via this helper reduces duplicated logic
30    across controllers and configuration validators.  Callers may still
31    choose to perform their own validation before construction, but using
32    this helper ensures consistent error messages and thresholds.
33    """
34    if value is None or not isinstance(value, (int, float)) or not math.isfinite(value):
35        raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a finite number; got {value!r}")
36    val = float(value)
37    if allow_zero:
38        if val < 0.0:
39            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be ≥ 0; got {val}")
40    else:
41        if val <= 0.0:
42            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be > 0; got {val}")
43    return val

require_in_range(value, name)¶

Validate that a numeric value lies within a closed or open interval.

Parameters¶

value : float or int or None The numeric quantity to validate. name : str The name of the parameter (used in the error message). minimum : float Lower bound of the allowed interval. maximum : float Upper bound of the allowed interval. allow_equal : bool, optional If True (default) the bounds are inclusive; if False the value must satisfy minimum < value < maximum.

Returns¶

float The validated value cast to float.

Raises¶

ValueError If value is None, not finite, or lies outside the specified interval.

Notes¶

Range constraints arise frequently in control law design; for example, a controllability threshold should be positive but small, whereas adaptation gains must lie within finite bounds to ensure stability【462167782799487†L186-L195】. Centralising range checks avoids duplicating logic across the project and produces uniform error messages.

Source Code¶

 1def require_in_range(value: float | int | None, name: str, *, minimum: float, maximum: float, allow_equal: bool = True) -> float:
 2    """Validate that a numeric value lies within a closed or open interval.
 3
 4    Parameters
 5    ----------
 6    value : float or int or None
 7        The numeric quantity to validate.
 8    name : str
 9        The name of the parameter (used in the error message).
10    minimum : float
11        Lower bound of the allowed interval.
12    maximum : float
13        Upper bound of the allowed interval.
14    allow_equal : bool, optional
15        If True (default) the bounds are inclusive; if False the value
16        must satisfy ``minimum < value < maximum``.
17
18    Returns
19    -------
20    float
21        The validated value cast to ``float``.
22
23    Raises
24    ------
25    ValueError
26        If ``value`` is ``None``, not finite, or lies outside the
27        specified interval.
28
29    Notes
30    -----
31    Range constraints arise frequently in control law design; for
32    example, a controllability threshold should be positive but small,
33    whereas adaptation gains must lie within finite bounds to ensure
34    stability【462167782799487†L186-L195】.  Centralising range checks
35    avoids duplicating logic across the project and produces uniform
36    error messages.
37    """
38    if value is None or not isinstance(value, (int, float)) or not math.isfinite(value):
39        raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a finite number; got {value!r}")
40    val = float(value)
41    if allow_equal:
42        if val < minimum or val > maximum:
43            raise ValueError(f"{name} must be in the interval [{minimum}, {maximum}]; got {val}")
44    else:
45        if val <= minimum or val >= maximum:
46            raise ValueError(f"{name} must satisfy {minimum} < {name} < {maximum}; got {val}")
47    return val

saturate(sigma, epsilon, method)¶

Continuous approximation of sign(sigma) within a boundary layer.

Args: sigma: Sliding surface value(s). epsilon: Boundary-layer half-width in σ-space (must be > 0). # ε is the half-width in σ-space. method: “tanh” (default) uses tanh(sigma/epsilon); “linear” uses clip(sigma/epsilon, -1, 1). Returns: Same shape as sigma.

Notes¶

The boundary layer width epsilon should be chosen based on the expected amplitude of measurement noise and the desired steady‑state accuracy. A larger epsilon reduces chattering but introduces a finite steady‑state error; conversely, a smaller epsilon reduces error but may increase high‑frequency switching【538884328193976†L412-L423】.

Raises: ValueError If epsilon <= 0 or an unknown method is provided.

Source Code¶

 1def saturate(
 2    sigma: float | np.ndarray,
 3    epsilon: float,
 4    method: Literal["tanh", "linear"] = "tanh",
 5) -> float | np.ndarray:
 6    """Continuous approximation of sign(sigma) within a boundary layer.
 7    
 8    Args:
 9        sigma: Sliding surface value(s).
10        epsilon: Boundary-layer half-width in σ-space (must be > 0).  # ε is the half-width in σ-space.
11        method: "tanh" (default) uses tanh(sigma/epsilon);
12                "linear" uses clip(sigma/epsilon, -1, 1).
13    Returns:
14        Same shape as `sigma`.
15
16    Notes
17    -----
18    The boundary layer width ``epsilon`` should be chosen based on the
19    expected amplitude of measurement noise and the desired steady‑state
20    accuracy.  A larger ``epsilon`` reduces chattering but introduces
21    a finite steady‑state error; conversely, a smaller ``epsilon`` reduces
22    error but may increase high‑frequency switching【538884328193976†L412-L423】.
23
24    Raises:
25        ValueError
26            If ``epsilon <= 0`` or an unknown ``method`` is provided.
27    """
28    if epsilon <= 0:
29        raise ValueError("boundary layer epsilon must be positive")
30    s = np.asarray(sigma, dtype=float) / float(epsilon)
31    if method == "tanh":
32        return np.tanh(s)
33    if method == "linear":
34        # Warn users that the linear saturation approximates sign(sigma) poorly
35        # near zero.  A piecewise‑linear approximation yields a sharp transition
36        # at the boundary layer and can introduce larger steady‑state errors.
37        # Sliding‑mode control theory recommends smooth approximations such
38        # as tanh to mitigate chattering【676964782857750†L146-L149】.
39        import warnings
40        warnings.warn(
41            "The 'linear' switching method implements a piecewise‑linear saturation, "
42            "which approximates the sign function poorly near zero and can degrade "
43            "chattering performance.  Consider using 'tanh' for smoother control.",
44            RuntimeWarning,
45        )
46        return np.clip(s, -1.0, 1.0)
47    raise ValueError(f"unknown saturation method: {method!r}")

Dependencies¶

This module imports:

  • from __future__ import annotations

  • import math

  • import numpy as np

  • from typing import Literal
